items.title: Britain weighs Greenland deployment as Trump threatens seizure

featured_image.name: British troops land 'in force' in Arctic region - UK Defence Journal

items.description:
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer is weighing military options in Greenland following escalating threats by US President Donald Trump to seize the Danish territory, with UK officials pursuing an urgent diplomatic strategy to defuse the most serious NATO crisis in the alliance's history.

Trump declared Friday that the United States would "do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," refusing to rule out military force to acquire the semi-autonomous Arctic island[1][2]. The Daily Mail reported Sunday that Trump has ordered special forces commanders to draw up invasion plans, though senior military officials are reportedly resisting the directive as unlawful[3][4].

The Telegraph reported Saturday that military planners are developing proposals for a potential NATO mission to Greenland that could involve British troops, warships and aircraft[5][6]. Downing Street has held discussions with German and French counterparts in recent days about deploying forces to demonstrate that Europe can address Arctic security concerns, according to British officials[7][5].

items.title: Iran protest death toll exceeds 500 amid crackdown, rights group says

featured_image.name: Iran cuts internet as protest movement against regime grows

items.description:
The death toll from two weeks of anti-government protests in Iran has climbed above 500, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency, as authorities impose a nationwide internet blackout and threaten demonstrators with the death penalty.

HRANA reported Sunday that 490 protesters and 48 security force members have been killed since demonstrations erupted on December 28, with approximately 10,000 people arrested[1][2][3][4]. Reuters could not independently verify the figures, and Iranian authorities have not released official casualty counts[1][2][3]. Some reports suggest the actual toll may be far higher, with one Tehran doctor telling TIME that at least 217 deaths had been recorded across six hospitals in the capital alone[5].

Medical staff at hospitals in Tehran, Rasht, and Shiraz described facilities overwhelmed by the wounded and dead. A hospital worker in Tehran told the BBC that casualties were so numerous that "there wasn't enough space in the morgue; the bodies were placed on top of one another"[6][7]. Another medic reported security forces firing "direct shots to the heads of the young people, to their hearts as well"[6][7]. BBC Persian verified that approximately 70 bodies were brought to Poursina Hospital in Rasht on Friday night, exceeding morgue capacity[7][8].

items.title: Iran warns US bases, Israel are 'legitimate targets'

featured_image.name: Iran warns Israel, US military and shipping centers would be ...

items.description:
Iran's parliament speaker issued a stark warning Sunday that American military bases across the Middle East and Israel would be considered "legitimate targets" if the United States launches strikes against the Islamic Republic, as President Donald Trump weighs military options to support anti-government protesters.

Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, speaking during a heated parliamentary session broadcast on state television, told lawmakers that Tehran would not limit itself to retaliatory strikes. "In the event of an attack on Iran, both the occupied territory and all American military centers, bases and ships in the region will be our legitimate targets," he said, using Iran's term for Israel[1][2][3]. "We do not consider ourselves limited to reacting after the action and will act based on any objective signs of a threat."

As Qalibaf spoke, lawmakers rushed the parliament dais chanting "Death to America," marking a sharp escalation in tensions[1][4].

items.title: Iran leader vows economic reform as death toll tops 160

featured_image.name: Iran's Pezeshkian pledges economic overhaul amid spiralling protests

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian pledged to overhaul his country's struggling economy on Sunday while accusing the United States and Israel of orchestrating nationwide protests that have left more than 160 dead, according to multiple reports.

In a televised address, Pezeshkian struck a conciliatory tone, saying his government is "ready to heed the voice of its people" and is "determined to resolve economic problems by any means possible"[1][2][3][4][5]. However, he urged Iranians to distance themselves from what he called "rioters and terrorists," claiming foreign powers are exploiting legitimate grievances to destabilize the country[1][2][6].

items.title: Former UK diplomat says he did not know about Epstein abuse
items.description: Peter Mandelson, who was fired as the UK's ambassador in Washington DC over his ties to the convicted sex offender, has apologised to victims of Jeffrey Epstein "for a system that refused to hear their voices".

items.title: Victoria's bushfire crisis turns deadly as conditions ease
items.description: On Sunday afternoon, emergency services discovered the body of a person in Central Victoria. The fatal turn comes as firefighters use favourable conditions to contain more than 20 blazes across the state.

items.title: Relaxed Medvedev claims Brisbane International crown
items.description: Daniil Medvedev enjoys Australian Open warm up with first Brisbane International crown.

items.title: At least 500 killed in Iran protests as Trump weighs up intervention
items.description: The US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency says a further 10,600 people have been arrested as Iran's theocratic government attempts to crack down on the demonstrations.

items.title: Adelaide Festival board members, chair quit after author's cancellation from Writers' Week
items.description: The Adelaide Festival board's decision to cancel the appearance of Palestinian-Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah from this year's Adelaide Writers' Week has prompted further fallout, with several board members and the chair stepping down.

items.title: SpaceX launches NASA's Pandora to study exoplanet atmospheres

featured_image.name: Watch SpaceX launch NASA's Pandora exoplanet-studying ...

items.description:
SpaceX launched NASA's Pandora satellite Sunday morning from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California, sending the first mission of NASA's Astrophysics Pioneers program to study the atmospheres of distant exoplanets[1][2][3].

The 716-pound satellite lifted off at 5:19 a.m. PST aboard a Falcon 9 rocket carrying about 40 payloads on the inaugural Twilight rideshare mission to sun-synchronous orbit[1][4][5]. The launch marked a new approach to exoplanet research, with Pandora designed to disentangle signals from planetary atmospheres and their host stars using simultaneous observations in visible and infrared light[2][6].

items.title: 'Mate, let's go again': Firefighter continues shift after home burns
items.description: CFA volunteer Michael Harper discovers through the truck radio while on shift that his home is under threat.

items.title: Property saved with mops, mates and rakes after fire encircles home
items.description: Everywhere you look around the Irvines' farm near Alexandra are signs of the fire that surrounded their home and burnt right up to the front porch.

items.title: US strikes over 35 ISIS sites in Syria with 90+ munitions

featured_image.name: US carries out additional 'large-scale' strikes on ISIS targets in Syria

items.description:
The United States and allied forces conducted extensive airstrikes against Islamic State targets across Syria on Saturday afternoon, firing more than 90 precision munitions at over 35 locations in the second major wave of a sustained military campaign to retaliate for the killing of three Americans last month[1][2][3][4][5].

The strikes, carried out at approximately 12:30 p.m. Eastern Time, involved more than 20 aircraft including F-15E Strike Eagles, A-10 Warthogs, AC-130J gunships, MQ-9 Reaper drones, and Jordanian F-16s, according to U.S. Central Command[1][4]. The military operation is part of Operation Hawkeye Strike, authorized by President Donald Trump on December 19 in response to a deadly ISIS ambush near Palmyra that killed two Iowa National Guard soldiers and a U.S. civilian interpreter on December 13[1][2][3][5].

items.title: Iran Guards call security a 'red line' amid 13th day of protests

featured_image.name: Iran's Guards Declare 'Red Line' on Security as Tehran Seeks ...

items.description:
Iran's Revolutionary Guards declared Saturday that safeguarding security is a "red line" as authorities escalated efforts to crush the largest anti-government protests in years, now entering their 13th consecutive day amid a nationwide internet blackout and mounting international pressure.

The warning from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, broadcast on state television, came as protests that began over soaring inflation on December 28 have evolved into calls for an end to clerical rule[1][2][3]. The elite force accused "terrorists" of targeting military and law enforcement bases and said continued unrest was "unacceptable"[1][4].

items.title: Venezuela frees 18 political prisoners after Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Venezuela releases imprisoned opposition figures, which ...

items.description:
Venezuela has released 18 political prisoners as of Saturday morning, following the U.S. military capture of President Nicolás Maduro one week earlier[1][2]. The prisoner releases mark the first concessions by Venezuela's interim government since U.S. forces seized Maduro in a raid on Caracas on January 3[3][4][5].

President Donald Trump announced Friday that he had canceled a planned "second wave of attacks" on Venezuela after the country began freeing detainees[3][6][7]. "Venezuela is releasing large numbers of political prisoners as a sign of 'Seeking Peace,'" Trump wrote on Truth Social, calling it "a very important and smart gesture"[3][8][7]. Trump said the U.S. and Venezuela "are working well together, especially as it pertains to rebuilding, in a much bigger, better, and more modern form, their oil and gas infrastructure"[3][7].

Jorge Rodríguez, president of Venezuela's National Assembly and brother of interim president Delcy Rodríguez, announced Thursday that a "significant number" of prisoners would be released immediately as a gesture to promote "peaceful coexistence"[3][5][9]. He did not specify how many would be freed or provide names[3][4][5].

items.title: The ABC was allowed in to Afghanistan. This is what we saw
items.description: Four years after the Taliban's return to power, security is no longer the defining issue in Afghanistan. Instead, one of the world's worst humanitarian crises is exacerbated by a series of overlapping disasters.

items.title: Astronomers reveal 'ghost galaxy' and platypus galaxies

featured_image.name: NASA's Hubble Examines Cloud-9, First of New Type of Object ...

items.description:
Astronomers presented two groundbreaking discoveries this week at the 247th meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Phoenix, unveiling celestial objects that challenge prevailing theories about how galaxies form and evolve.

Using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, researchers confirmed the first-ever detection of a starless dark matter cloud dubbed Cloud-9, located 14 million light-years from Earth near the spiral galaxy Messier 94[1][2][3][4][5][6]. The object represents a category called Reionization-Limited H I Clouds, or RELHICs—theoretical "failed galaxies" that never accumulated enough gas to ignite star formation[1][2][3][7][8][9].

"This is a tale of a failed galaxy," said Alejandro Benitez-Llambay, an astrophysicist at the University of Milano-Bicocca in Milan, Italy, who serves as the study's principal investigator[1][10][11]. The findings, published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters in November 2025, were presented Monday at the conference[1][8][11].

Cloud-9's core spans roughly 4,900 light-years and contains about one million solar masses of neutral hydrogen gas[1][3][8]. Yet calculations suggest the cloud sits within a dark matter halo weighing approximately five billion solar masses—mass that provides gravitational structure without producing visible light[1][3][12].

"Cloud-9 gives us a rare look at a dark-matter-dominated cloud," said Andrew Fox, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute for the European Space Agency[1][3][13].

The discovery began three years ago when China's Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope detected the hydrogen cloud during a radio survey[1][2][3][4][14][15]. Subsequent observations from the Green Bank Telescope and Very Large Array confirmed the gas presence, but only Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys could definitively rule out stars[1][3][4][8][13].

"Before we used Hubble, you could argue that this is a faint dwarf galaxy that we could not see with ground-based telescopes," said lead author Gagandeep Anand of the Space Telescope Science Institute[3][13][12]. "But with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys, we're able to nail down that there's nothing there."

items.title: Intense rainfall follows ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji in sodden north Queensland
items.description: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji has crossed the north Queensland coast between the towns of Ayr and Bowen and has weakened into a tropical low pressure system.

items.title: 'Only thing missing is my eight-year-old daughter': Father's chilling report
items.description: Fifty years after Beaumaris schoolgirl Eloise Worledge vanished, could new leads solve one of Australia's most haunting cold cases?

items.title: Greenland parliament unites to reject Trump acquisition threats

featured_image.name: Greenland's Democrats want broad coalition to show unity in face of Trump pressure

items.description:
President Donald Trump intensified his push to acquire Greenland on Friday, declaring the United States will "do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," as the world's largest island becomes a flashpoint for geopolitical tensions over its vast mineral wealth and strategic Arctic position[1][2][3].

All five political parties in Greenland's parliament issued a unified rejection hours later. "We do not want to be Americans, we do not want to be Danes, we want to be Greenlanders," the leaders stated in a rare joint declaration, announcing an expedited parliamentary session to address the escalating U.S. threats[2][4]. The island's 57,000 residents have consistently rejected Trump's overtures, with Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen reiterating that "Greenland is not for sale"[1][3].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
